title.narrative: SAFE+ Adressera bränslebehov, miljöförstöring och matsäkerhet Cox's Bazar
SAFE+ Cooking Fuel Need, Environmental Degradation and Food Security Cox's Bazar

description.narrative: Goal: Contribute to the overall food and nutrition security, empowerment and resilience of 125,000 refugee and host community households in Cox’s Bazar Objective 1: Targeted households, especially women headed and vulnerable households have monthly decreased expenditures related to firewood purchase Objective 2: Vulnerable households in host communities, especially women and girls, are more resilient through increased income Objective 3: Refugee households feel more resilient after participating in the skills development training Objective 4: Negative environmental impacts are mitigated through land/forest rehabilitation

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 IOM har genom sin roll som sammankallande agent för det gemensamma FN-programmet SAFE Plus "Adressera bränslebehov, miljöförstöring och matsäkerhet Cox's Bazar" ansökt om finansiering för genomförandet av programmet under perioden 2019-2021. Programmet har utformats under ledning av Flykting, stöd- och repatrieringskommissionen (RRRC) under ministeriet för katastrofhantering och stöd (MoDMR) och bidrar till lokal förvaltningsplanering och den gemensamma humanitära åtgärdsplanen via Inter-Sector Coordination Group (ISCG). Insatsen kommer endast stödja aktiviteter i Cox's Bazar distrikt.
Målet med programmet är att bidra till den övergripande mat- och näringssäkerheten, självstärkande och motståndskraften för 125 000 flykting- och värdhushåll i Cox's Bazar. Programmet har fyra mål, varav det första är att tillgodose det brådskande behovet av matlagningsbränsle för rohingya-flyktingar och värdsamhällen i Cox's Bazar, genom att införa alternativt rent matlagningsbränsle och teknik. Det andra och tredje primära målet fokuserar på att förbättra ekonomiska livsförhållanden för värdsamhällen (och i sin tur övergripande matsäkerhet) genom utbildning och alternativa försörjningsmöjligheter samt flyktingars ökade motståndskraft genom kompetensutveckling. Det fjärde målet syftar till att mildra negativ miljöpåverkan genom rehabilitering av mark-och skogsområden.
Det gemensamma programmet genomförs av tre FN-organ; IOM, WFP och FAO och deras partners. Den riktar sig till 125 000 hushåll (100 000 rohingya-flyktingar och 25 000 värdhushåll). Implementeringsperioden är september 2018 till december 2021 med en total budget på 117,5 miljoner USD. Sveriges bidrag är 100 miljoner kronor, varav 25 miljoner kronor finansieras av Sveriges regerings klimatsatsning för minskade utsläpp 2019. Andra utvecklingspartners som har gett bidrag är Kanada, DFID, Australien, Norge, ECHO, Nederländerna, Japan, Korea och USA. Cirka 29% av programmets totala finansieringsbehov har täckts.
Förutom SAFE Plus-programmet riktar UNHCR distribution av gasol till ytterligare 125 000 hushåll (100 000 rohingya-flyktingar och 25 000 värdhushåll), vilket innebär att alla hushåll i lägren kommer att täckas. Sverige bidrar genom sin humanitära finansiering med 50 miljoner kronor till UNHCR 2019 för distribution av gasol och för pilotprojekt av energisparande initiativ, som i ett senare skede kan skalas upp till alla hushåll som använder gasol. Dessa är kompletterande medel till stödet till SAFE Plus-programmet för att möjliggöra att alla flyktinghushåll får tillgång till rent matlagningsbränsle.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 IOM through its role as the Convening Agency (CA) for the joint UN program SAFE Plus "Address Cooking Fuel Needs, Environmental Degradation and Food Security Cox's Bazar" has applied for funding for implementation of the program during the period 2019-2021. The program has been designed under the direction of the Refugee Relief and Repatriation Commission (RRRC) of the Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief (MoDMR) and contributes to local government planning and the Joint Response Plan of the Inter-Sector Coordination Group (ISCG). The contribution will only support activities in Cox's Bazar district.
The goal of the program is to contribute to the overall food and nutrition security, empowerment and resilience of 125,000 refugee and host community households in Cox’s Bazar. The program has four objectives, the first of which is to address the urgent cooking fuel needs of Rohingya refugees and host communities in Cox's Bazar, by introducing alternative clean cooking fuel and technology. The second and third primary objective focuses on improving economic livelihoods for host community members (and in turn overall food security) through training and inputs provision as well as the resilience of refugees through empowerment skills development. The fourth objective aims at mitigating negative environmental impacts through land/forest rehabilitation.
The joint program is implemented by three UN agencies; IOM, WFP and FAO, and their partners. It targets 125,000 households (100,000 Rohingya refugees and 25,000 host community households). The period of implementation is September 2018 to December 2021 with an total estimated budget of 117.5 million USD. Sweden's contribution is 100 million SEK out of which 25 million SEK is financed by the Swedish Government's climate initiative on reduced emissions in 2019. Other development partners who have committed contributions are Canada, DFID, Australia, Norway, ECHO, Netherlands, Japan, Korea and the United States. Around 29 % of the total funding needs for the program has been covered.
In addition to the SAFE Plus program, UNHCR is targeting an additional 125,000 households (100,000 Rohingya refugees and 25,000 host community households) for LPG distribution which means that all households in camps will be covered. Sweden is through its humanitarian funding contributing 50 million SEK to UNHCR in 2019 for LPG distribution and for piloting energy saving initiatives which could at a later stage be scaled up to all households using LPG. These are complementary funds to the support to the SAFE Plus program so all refugee households will have access to clean cooking fuel.

sector.narrative: Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

title.narrative: Amendment agreement of SAFE+ Cooking Fuel CXB 2019 _12515
Amendment agreement of SAFE+ Cooking Fuel CXB 2019 _12515_SAA ADD2

description.narrative: The primary aim of the SAFE Plus programme is to contribute to the overall food and nutrition security, empowerment and resilience of 125,000 Rohingya and host community households in Cox’s Bazar. To achieve this, the programme has four objectives, the first of which is to address the urgent cooking fuel needs of Rohingyas and host communities in Cox's Bazar, by introducing alternative clean cooking fuel and technology. The second objective focuses on livelihoods and income generation for the heavily impacted host community through training and inputs provision and the third objective is the self-reliance of selected Rohingya, with a focus on women. The fourth objective aims at mitigating negative environmental impacts through land and forest rehabilitation. The objectives address short, medium and longer-term challenges with activities benefitting both the Rohingya and host community populations, and therefore contributing to social cohesion. The programme experienced disruptions to the implementation during 2020, due to the outbreak of Covid-19 and the Government-declared nationwide lockdown which lasted from 23 March to 30 May 2020. The situation as continously been challenging even though most activities could resume in late 2020. Objective 1: Targeted households, especially women headed and vulnerable households have monthly decreased expenditures related to firewood purchase The programme has provided 133,421 households (104,063 in the refugee camps, i.e. 71,803 men and 32,260 women headed households; and 29,358 in host communities, i.e. 23,486 men and 5,872 women headed households) with LPG packages. As per the midterm evaluation report, 98% of the households reported decreased monthly expenditure from baseline BDT 630 (USD 7.44) to BDT 201 (USD 2.37) on firewood purchase since the provision of alternative fuel, namely LPG stove sets and gas refills. The percentage of beneficiaries who adopted one or more negative food-related coping strategies has reduced from the baseline of 70% to 48% (the end of programme target was 50%). Average household income increased by 13% (from BDT 13,228, i.e. USD 156.03 in the baseline to BDT 14,950, i.e. USD 176.35). Throughout the programme, in order to reduce firewood consumption in 17 targeted camps, 1,001,944 LPG refills were delivered to the host and Rohingya communities. Objective 2: Vulnerable households in host communities, especially women and girls, are more resilient through increased income The accomplished livelihoods activities have contributed to increasing the market compatibilities of the local agricultural farmers through providing agricultural inputs, training on improved agricultural practices, climate-resilient nutrition-sensitive production growth and connecting with the market using multiple channels. As a result, 53 per cent of targeted household from host communities reported increase in income, from the baseline of BDT 13,228 (USD 156.03) to BDT 14,950 (USD 176.35)(i.e. 13% increase). The off-farm activities of the programme were jointly implemented by IOM and WFPand a total of 11,837 households (10,658 women and 1,179 men) were identified through the joint assessments applying the WFP vulnerability criteria and received cash grants, training, inputs support and market linkage over the year. FAO supported a total of 1,440 farmers with trainings on production technologies, integrated pest management, risk reduction in agriculture collective production, and market linkages, contributing to the increased production. The programme also prioritized gender-sensitive agricultural practices enabling the farmer groups, particularly women, to participate in the agricultural transformation processes. The programme included at least 35% women in the farmer groups. The programme has a key focus on building the collective capacity of the farmer groups to enable them to increase production and income by adopting integrated approaches. FAO facilitated the establishment of eight Aggregation Centers. The Aggregation Center Management Committee (ACMC) established linkages with 56 farmer groups and have been so far connected to markets through these Aggregation Centers, which helped farmers obtain better prices for their products, connect with buyers, output markets, local buyers, and wholesalers. In response to the Covid-19, FAO provided Aman rice seeds among 23,977 vulnerablefarmers (i.e. 10 kg for every farmer), and 83% of the farmers planted these rice seeds producing 18,309 metric tons of rice. Objective 3: Refugee households feel more resilient after participating in the skills development training The self-reliance activities has faced a long-term delay in the implementation due to the government restrictions on such activities in the camps. IOM initiated the implementation in the fourth quarter of 2020 after receiving the approval from the government and assisted 2,584 rohingya individuals to increase the self-reliance capacity involving them in home gardening activities. Objective 4: Negative environmental impacts are mitigated through land/forest rehabilitation Through satellite imagery analysis in 2018, FAO identified degraded areas inside the camps and categorized them according to the degradation level. This helped to prioritize degraded land that needed to be restored. By the end of 2020, FAO had restored 2,259 ha of degraded forest land, which accounted for 100% of the target outside of the camps and 52% of the target inside the camps. Landscaping tools and equipment were purchased and trees, leguminous plants, bamboo saplings and log-rooted grasses were planted in camps. This activity contributed to attainment of faster vegetative coverage inside the camp areas and reduced landslide vulnerability. Cash for work strategy was adopted for land and forest rehabilitation in both camps as well as host community areas which contributed to the livelihood and income of both host communities and refugees. The total cash-for-work days achieved is 110,531 person days focused on reforestation and maintenance activities throughout the whole programme period. One of the important inputs for reforestation of the damaged forest areas was seedlings. The programme hence raised nurseries of trees and grasses that were later transplanted in vulnerable areas. Suitable lands were identified for raising nursery through survey and mapping, lands were prepared for nursery development, nursery beds were developed, sheds were constructed and water pumps installed. Seedlings produced in these local nurseries were procured by SAFE Plus with certification from Forest Department. In total, out of the targeted 20 nurseries, 17 nurseries have been established, which include 15 temporary nurseries and two permanent nurseries. FAO, in collaboration with the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), has assessed the floral diversity of the forest areas under the Cox’s Bazar South Forest Division. This document will be of great assistance for the conservationists to choose the right site-specific species for the restoration initiatives. Key findings in the mid term evaluation - the percentage of beneficiaries who adopted one or more negative food-related coping strategies has reduced from the baseline of 70% to 48% (the end of programme target was 50%). The reduction was more in host communities (43 percent) than in Rohingya refugees (52 percent). - the programme contributed to a significant reduction of use of firewood due to the introduction of LPG, and by doing so, attributed considerably in the overall improvement of the health of the beneficiaries, environmental degradation, and reduction of greenhouse gas emission. - the business model established within the host community in which the producers targeting Rohingya households as market for their produced commodities is a crucial contributing factor in reducing tension between these two communities. - considerable expansion of distribution network was seen from the private LPG companies in Cox’s Bazar area, with quite a number of non-beneficiaries using the gas for cooking purpose. This can also be attributed to the efforts of SAFE Plus and other LPG gas distribution interventions in the area. - gender sensitivity is in-built within the programme design and implementation. Programme interventions reduced the need for women and girls to go to forest areas to collect firewood, and thereby reduced the risks of violence, injuries and trafficking. SAFE Plus also contributed positively in improving health conditions of the beneficiaries. Other Assessments - WFP conducted a tailored social cohesion assessment to measure the impact of resilience building activities on the social cohesion levels. This included measuring the impact on inter-community, intra-community relations, trust levels and accountability. It was found that livelihoods activities had most impact on social cohesion with 98% of the respondents stating that the programme had infused positive change in the relationships, which woud be sustainable over time. - 85% of livelihoods, 62% of the cash for work and 65% of the Self Reliance participants in the host community mentioned that the income generated through the programme participation had improved their ability to help others and in turn improved their relationships with the community members. As compared to the non-participants, the participants showed greater trust levels and participation across social platforms. - a Floral Diversity Assessment and development of SMART Guideline for the Hilly and Plain land forest to ensure better management and sustainability was conducted. FAO, IUCN, and Forest Department collaborated on it. FAO piloted Dry season planting mechanism inside the camps and is waiting to get the assessment results. It would help in expanding SAFE Plus environmental restoration initiatives beyond the monsoon plantation season.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
